Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The project is implementing a comprehensive, integrated, multi-layered approach for increasing the number of STEM majors across the State of Washington by coordinating articulation and matriculation between the Washington MESA Community College Program, the University of Washington, and Washington State University. The comprehensive approach is being achieved through established synergy and strong institutional support at the partner colleges and universities. The project, a follow-on to a prior STEP award, is (1) expanding its focus from engineering to all STEM disciplines while strongly emphasizing the inclusion of underrepresented students, (2) increasing the number of community colleges active in the consortium, (3) standardizing the retention and transfer services and activities by migrating towards the successful MESA Community College STEM transfer model, (4) institutionalizing the MESA academic support model for STEM transfers at participating community colleges, and (5) replicating the successful components and services of the MESA K-20 Pathway across Washington. They are disseminating the project's findings and best practices at professional technical society meetings and through organizations such as the National Action Council of Minority Engineering Program Administrators (NAMEPA), Society for the Advancement of Chicanos and Native Americans in the Sciences (SACNAS), and National Society of Black Engineers (NSBE). A workforce development center at the University of Washington is monitoring progress towards the project goals by collecting and analyzing data on the number of students and their grades, retention and transfer rates, self confidence levels, and impressions of program effectiveness. Broader impacts include a major focus on increasing the participation of underrepresented minority students and the dissemination of the projects' approaches and evaluation results.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Summary:  The creation of the Washington MESA Community College Program (WA-MCCP) is a consortium of 6 community colleges and two state university systems aimed at increasing the number of successful STEM transfers to university. Historically underrepresented students was the stated priority, with targeted outreach and core components to provide both academic and social support structures for MCCP students. Nearly 70% of participants are from historically underrepresented minority groups, and MCCP students must have financial need and be first generation college-bound.   

Developing infrastructure to support  project goals and outcomes, while employing strategies of the project was key to the success of this model. This includes a MESA staff at each site, with a dedicated director and faculty sponsor, and a responsible administrator. The designated student space was the most challenging component, but by the end of the grant, the six campuses had institutionalized their MESA Centers. The implementation and success of the MESA academic support transfer model has also been possible due to strengthening of relationships between the partner institutions.  

Impact: The inherent consortium structure of this project, which includes community colleges and major universities throughout the state, supports many student activities at any given time. The 6 major core components, all of which are structured to engage students, are geared to ensure student success. Campuses submit a yearly plan via a logic model that itemizes activities, timeline, expected outcome and budgetary impact. This integral tool for assuring the MCCP model was standardized from campus to campus and across the state, provides students quality service in engaging and meaningful ways. A few highlights include:

MESA Week or MESA Days, including engineering competitions, professional development and academic preparation workshops, meet and greet with professionals, STEM career exploration days

Campus Visits to Partnering Universities, students participate in information sessions to assist with successful navigation to transfer, STEM advising, and meet previously transferred students to learn from their experiences.

Student Center Activities and Workshops, including admissions, financial aid, educational planning, learning styles and time management, career exploration and professional development, etc.

Guest Speakers and Mentoring via connections to STEM professionals.

Unanticipated Partnerships:  At least three strong partnerships are now thriving; The Pacific Northwest Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation. (PNW LSAMP) has written MCCP into its’ program plan. Undergraduate research opportunities, STEM career development and attendance at LSAMP conferences have been extended to MCCP students.  IBM, Accenture and other industry partners, have launched partnership initiatives with WA MCCP, including a recent IBM Blue Mix/MCCP Mobile Apps Challenge and the upcoming Leadership and Professional Development Training sponsored by Accenture. The Washington State Board of Community and Technical Colleges (SBCTC) has become a strong and supportive partner to MESA. In the final year of the grant, SBCTC provided the needed support to educate policy leaders in the state in order to secure funding in the state budget for MCCP sustainability.

Lessons Learned: Nationally, MCCP has existed since 1991. Although successful STEM transfer is clearly a product of this program, unless there is a well-planned and focused effort, providing campus/local resources remains a challenge. Additionally, to support and develop students academically and professionally, as well as provide advising in areas such as financial aid,...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Project Summary: The creation of the Washington MESA Community College Program (WA-MCCP) is a consortium of 6 community colleges and two state university systems aimed at increasing the number of successful STEM transfers to university. Historically underrepresented students was the stated priority, with targeted outreach and core components to provide both academic and social support structures for MCCP students. Nearly 70% of participants are from historically underrepresented minority groups, and MCCP students must have financial need and be first generation college-bound. Developing infrastructure to support project goals and outcomes, while employing strategies of the project was key to the success of this model. This includes a MESA staff at each site, with a dedicated director and faculty sponsor, and a responsible administrator. The designated student space was the most challenging component, but by the end of the grant, the six campuses had institutionalized their MESA Centers. The implementation and success of the MESA academic support transfer model has also been possible due to strengthening of relationships between the partner institutions. Impact: The inherent consortium structure of this project, which includes community colleges and major universities throughout the state, supports many student activities at any given time. The 6 major core components, all of which are structured to engage students, are geared to ensure student success. Campuses submit a yearly plan via a logic model that itemizes activities, timeline, expected outcome and budgetary impact. This integral tool for assuring the MCCP model was standardized from campus to campus and across the state, provides students quality service in engaging and meaningful ways. A few highlights include: MESA Week or MESA Days, including engineering competitions, professional development and academic preparation workshops, meet and greet with professionals, STEM career exploration days Campus Visits to Partnering Universities, students participate in information sessions to assist with successful navigation to transfer, STEM advising, and meet previously transferred students to learn from their experiences. Student Center Activities and Workshops, including admissions, financial aid, educational planning, learning styles and time management, career exploration and professional development, etc. Guest Speakers and Mentoring via connections to STEM professionals. Unanticipated Partnerships: At least three strong partnerships are now thriving; The Pacific Northwest Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation. (PNW LSAMP) has written MCCP into itsÃ† program plan. Undergraduate research opportunities, STEM career development and attendance at LSAMP conferences have been extended to MCCP students. IBM, Accenture and other industry partners, have launched partnership initiatives with WA MCCP, including a recent IBM Blue Mix/MCCP Mobile Apps Challenge and the upcoming Leadership and Professional Development Training sponsored by Accenture. The Washington State Board of Community and Technical Colleges (SBCTC) has become a strong and supportive partner to MESA. In the final year of the grant, SBCTC provided the needed support to educate policy leaders in the state in order to secure funding in the state budget for MCCP sustainability. Lessons Learned: Nationally, MCCP has existed since 1991. Although successful STEM transfer is clearly a product of this program, unless there is a well-planned and focused effort, providing campus/local resources remains a challenge. Additionally, to support and develop students academically and professionally, as well as provide advising in areas such as financial aid, study skills, time management and transfer shock require a versatile and dedicated person – the job is demanding and diverse. Leveraging collaboration for student success and institutional change is critical for increasing URM in STEM discipline...
